moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4
comment: Mednis is more a of positional player than a tactical player, so it is not so surprising that he should choose this continuation over the more aggressive 8.g4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6
comment: Intending Bc8-b7 to pressure White's e4-pawn.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4
comment: If 9.0-0 then 9...Bb7 and White must play 10.f3 after which Black can choose between 10...d5 or 10...Rc8.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8
comment: With a view to sacrificing the Exchange on c3. The solid 10...Be7 is also possible.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3
comment: A thematic Sicilian Exchange sacrifice - removing a key defender of the e4-pawn. The line 11...Qc7? 12.Qe1 Be7 13.Rd1 0-0 14.g4! with a clear advantage for White is given by Mednis and Byrne in Informant, but I would never play such an inferior variation as this. In a game against Tal, I chose the possibly superior 11...Be7 12.e5 Bxf3 13.Qxf3 dxe5 14.Nc6 Qc7 15.Nxe7 Kxe7, with an unclear position, and Black went on to win, Tal-Browne, Milan 1975. Coverage of the Tal game is to be found on my forthcoming video "Beating the Soviet Champions. "

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4
comment: Black's compensation for the sacrificed Exchange includes the capture of White's valuable e-pawn, play against White's fractured queenside pawn structure and good prospects for his minor pieces.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2
comment: Passive. Probably better is 13.c4. Note that 13.f5 e5 14.Ne2 Qc7 is promising for Black. After 13.Bxe4 Bxe4 14.Nf3 Be7 15.Nd2 Bb7, I would be very happy, as my bishop is even stronger here than in the main line.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1
comment: White's queen is not well placed here. The Black knight covers g3, and after Bf8-e7 the h4 square is also covered. There appears to be little point to this move if Qe1-g3 or Qe1-Qh4 are not possible. Black has good control of center, sufficient material , and good prospects in the center. If 14.Qd4 (eyeing my pawn on b6), then 14...e5 15.Qd3 Ndc5 16.Qc4 d5 17.Qa2 (if 17.Qb4 a5) and the White queen has been on a road to nowhere.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5
comment: Increasing my grip on the center, but it was also possible to play simply with 14...Be7.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4
comment: If 15.Bxe4 dxe4, and Black intends a6-a5 and an exchange of dark squared bishops followed by Nd7-c5 and targeting the weak a4-pawn (with Bb7-c6).

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3
comment: If 16.Bxc5 Qxc5+ followed by Nd7-f6 with a great game for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5
comment: Of course not 16...Qxf4?? 17.Bxe4 losing a piece for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3
comment: If 17.Nxe4 dxe4 and Black is much better.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5
comment: Denying Black's Nd7 a route to c4. After 19.Bxe4 dxe4 and the Black's two pawns hold White's three on the queenside, and Black has a dangerous mobile 5-3 majority on the kingside.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5
comment: A surprising break in the center which threatens 20...exf4 winning a piece and 20.fxe5 is not possible as 20...f4 wins.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2
comment: Not 20.Bxe4? dxe4 21.fxe5 Qxe5 22.Qf4 Qxf4 23.Rxf4 g6 24.Rd1 (or 24.Rb1 Bc6, followed by Bc6-b5-c4 and/or Ne5-c6 or Ne5-c4, with a big advantage for Black.) 24...Ne5 with a clear advantage for Black.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5
comment: An uncompromising method of maintaining the initiative. Black's wall of pawns on the fourth rank make an impressive sight. A good alternative is 20...d4 21.Qd3 c4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5
comment: Instead 21.Bxe4 gxf4 22.Bxd5+ Bxd5 23.Qd3 was necessary (as pointed out by Byrne and Mednis) although Black is still a lot better. Nor does 21.g3 gxf4 22.gxf4 Kh8 (with the idea Rf8-g8) 23.Kh1 d4 look very good for White.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1
comment: If 22.Qd3 Nxe5 with the idea of Nc4-e3.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5
comment: Let's take stock. White's Ne2 has nowhere to go. White's Bf3 can take on e4, but d5xe4 would give Black a dangerous four on two majority with possibilities of e4-e3 (followed by Qc7-c6) or f4-f3 coming.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4
comment: Guarding the b6 entry point and eliminating White's only possible counterplay. Black's powerfully posted knights are vastly superior to White's passive rooks.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1
comment: Black wins back the Exchange securing a material advantage and a clearly winning game.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2
comment: Also good is 26...Ne3, with the idea g5-g4.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2 27. Bxd5+
comment: Desperate times lead to desperate measures. I was about to ice the game with Nd2xf3+, so Mednis resorted to this petite combination that ultimately backfires.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2 27. Bxd5+ Bxd5 28. Qd1 Rd8
comment: Refuting Edmar's last hopes.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2 27. Bxd5+ Bxd5 28. Qd1 Rd8 29. Qxd2 Bxg2 30. Qe1 Ba8
comment: The long diagonal is completely opened with fatal consequences for White.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2 27. Bxd5+ Bxd5 28. Qd1 Rd8 29. Qxd2 Bxg2 30. Qe1 Ba8 31. h4 Qc6 32. Kh2 Qh6 33. Ng1 g4
comment: Black is completely winning, but because I was short on time (about 30 seconds left) Mednis played on to the time control at move 40. As we shall see, the threat of g4-g3 is devastating and I require only a few more moves to seal the win. With only a few seconds left on my clock, I missed the simple mate with 33...Qxh4+ 34.Nh3 Qg3 mate.

moves: 1. e4 c5 2. Nf3 d6 3. d4 cxd4 4. Nxd4 Nf6 5. Nc3 a6 6. Be2 Nbd7 7. Be3 e6 8. a4 b6 9. f4 Bb7 10. Bf3 Rc8 11. O-O Rxc3 12. bxc3 Nxe4 13. Ne2 Qc7 14. Qe1 d5 15. Bd4 Bc5 16. Ng3 f5 17. Qe3 O-O 18. Bxc5 bxc5 19. a5 e5 20. Ne2 g5 21. fxe5 f4 22. Qc1 Nxe5 23. Rb1 Nc4 24. Qe1 Ned2 25. Rf2 Nxb1 26. Qxb1 Nd2 27. Bxd5+ Bxd5 28. Qd1 Rd8 29. Qxd2 Bxg2 30. Qe1 Ba8 31. h4 Qc6 32. Kh2 Qh6 33. Ng1 g4 34. Qe7 Rf8 35. Rd2 g3+ 36. Kh3 Qg6 37. Rd6
comment: It was necessary to play 37.Qg5 entering a completely losing ending for White.
